book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. O Lord, make it easy and help. Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Hamad bin Hamid informed us, by reading to him, he said: Abu Al-Hasan Ali bin Al-Husayn bin Umar Al-Farra informed us, he said: The two Sheikhs, Abu Ishaq Ibrahim bin Said bin Abdullah Al-Habbal and Abu Zakariya Abdul Rahim bin Ahmad Al-Bukhari informed me, they said: Abdul Ghani bin Said Al-Hafiz informed, he said:

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: The Escape of Abu Amr bin Al-Ala from Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf and his Hiding from him in Yemen. 1 - Abu Muhammad Abdullah bin Ja'far bin Muhammad bin Al-Ward told us by dictation, Abu Ishaq Ibrahim bin Hamid Al-Basri the Judge told us, Abu Hatim Sahl bin Muhammad bin Uthman Al-Sijistani told us, Al-Asma'i told us on the authority of Abu Amr bin Al-Ala, who said:

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: Al-Hajjaj frightened me, so I fled to Yemen. I entered a house in Sana'a; I would appear on its roof at night and hide inside it during the day. He said: So, while I was on the roof of that house one early morning, I heard a man reciting: 'Perhaps souls panic from an affair... for which there is a release (furjah) like the undoing of a hobble cord.'

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: He said: I said, 'A release (furjah)?' He said: So I was pleased by it. He said: Then another person said, 'Al-Hajjaj has died.' He said: By Allah, I do not know with which of the two I was happier: his saying 'a release' or his saying 'Al-Hajjaj has died.' 2 - Abu Ali Al-Hasan bin Al-Khalil bin Qawam Al-Himyari told us, Abu Ja'far

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Salama [told us], Ahmad bin Abi Imran told us, Abu Nasr Ahmad bin Hatim told us on the authority of Al-Asma'i, on the authority of Abu Amr bin Al-Ala, who said: Al-Hajjaj employed my father for some of his works, then he became resentful towards him. So my father went out to the desert of his people and hid there, and I was with him. While we were there in the magic hours of dawn (Sahar), a rider approached saying: 'Perhaps souls panic from an affair... for which there is a release (furjah) like the undoing of a hobble cord.' He said: I said, 'What is that?' He said: 'Al-Hajjaj has died.' By Allah, I do not know with which of the two I was more overjoyed: 'Al-Hajjaj has died' or his saying 'a release.'

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: Mention of the Hiding of Al-Hasan bin Abi Al-Hasan Al-Basri from Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf.

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: Al-Hasan's hiding place was in the house of Abu Khalifa Al-Hajjaj bin Attab, and he was one of the Tabi'in (Successors). He has a son who narrates Hadith called Umar bin Abi Khalifa, who narrates from Muhammad bin Ziyad Abu Al-Harith Al-Jumahi. 3 - Hisham told us, Abu Ja'far Al-Tahawi told us, Ahmad bin Dawud told us, Ibn Aisha told us,

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: Hammad bin Salama told us on the authority of Humayd, who said: I read the entire Quran to Al-Hasan while he was hiding in the house of Abu Khalifa. He interpreted it for me with verification. Malik bin Dinar used to visit Al-Hasan in that hiding place. This is confirmed by Hadith 4 - which Al-Walid bin Al-Qasim told me, Al-Hasan bin Ali bin Musa Al-Nakkhas told us, Muhammad bin Abdul Malik bin Abi Al-Shawarib told us, Ja'far bin Sulaiman Al-Duba'i told us, saying: We were with Al-Hasan, may Allah have mercy on him, at Abu Khalifa Al-Abdi's place. He said: A man came to him and said, 'O Abu Said, I saw Abu Hamza wearing a silken (Khazz) jubbah.' Al-Hasan said, 'That I cut my dry bread and eat it is dearer to me than wearing a silken jubbah.' 5 - Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Jabir Al-Hajari told us, Ishaq bin Ahmad bin Ja'far Al-Qattan told us, Abu Said Al-Ashajj told us, Isa bin Yunus told us, Al-Ala bin Al-Mughira Al-Bundar told us, saying: Al-Hasan was informed of the death of Al-Hajjaj, so he prostrated. Abdullah bin Ja'far bin Al-Ward told us, Ali bin Muhammad bin Hayyun told us, Muhammad bin Hisham told us, Sufyan bin Uyainah told us on the authority of Abu Uthman who said: When Al-Hasan heard of Al-Hajjaj's death, he said: 'O Allah, You killed him, so cut off his sunnah (legacy).' And he used to say, 'A little man with weak eyes came to us, he has a close female relative whom he hates, a wretch among the wretches. By Allah, a dust of battle in the path of Allah never stuck under his clothes.' Abdul Ghani said: Abu Uthman is Amr bin Ubaid, and Allah knows best.

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: The Hiding of Abdullah bin Al-Harith Al-Hashimi (Babbah) from Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf.

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: Muhammad bin Saad, the scribe of Al-Waqidi, said: Abdullah bin Al-Harith bin Nawfal bin Al-Harith bin Abdul Muttalib bin Hisham, nicknamed Abu Muhammad, is the one whom the people of Basra nicknamed 'Babbah'. He perished in Oman at the end of the Fitnah (sedition) of Ibn Al-Ash'ath. He had gone out to it fleeing from Al-Hajjaj. He was born in the time of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and heard from Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, his sermon at Al-Jabiyah.

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: The Hiding of Ibrahim bin Yazid Al-Nakha'i Abu Imran the Jurist from Al-Hajjaj. 6 - Hisham bin Muhammad Al-Ruayni told us, Abu Ja'far Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Salama told us, Muhammad bin Ali bin Dawud told us, Said bin Sulaiman informed us on the authority of Ibn Shihab Al-Zuhri, the Scholar, son of Amr, who said:

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: We hid Ibrahim in his house when he disappeared from Al-Hajjaj, and he did not pray in congregation out of fear of Al-Hajjaj. 7 - Hisham bin Muhammad told us, Abu Ja'far Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Salama told us, Ibn Abi Dawud told us, Said bin Mansur told us, Mahdi bin Maimun told us on the authority of Shu'ayb bin Al-Habhab who said: Ibrahim was hiding from Al-Hajjaj, and he passed away and was buried at night. I attended the prayer over him, then I came to Al-Sha'bi, and he said: 'A man has passed away this night who has left no one like him behind.' I said: 'In Kufa?' He said: 'Neither in Kufa, nor in Basra, nor in Medina, nor in Mecca.' And when he spoke, he spoke in rhymed prose (Saj'). 8 - And in the oral transmission of Ali bin Umar to me with his authorization to me, from Uthman bin Ahmad bin Al-Sammak, from Hanbal, from Muhammad bin Dawud, from Isa bin Yunus, from Al-A'mash, who said: I saw Ibrahim wearing two leather socks or a Quba (outer garment), may Allah excuse him, looking like a Nabatian arriving from the countryside. He said: And that was because Al-Hajjaj was seeking him. 9 - Abu Abdullah Al-Husayn bin Muhammad bin Salam told us, Ishaq bin Ahmad bin Ja'far (who is Al-Qattan) told us, Ziyad bin Ayyub told us, Ismail bin Ulayyah told us on the authority of Ibn Awn,

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: He said: I brought Ibrahim the glad tidings of Al-Hajjaj's death, and he wept. I never thought anyone would weep out of joy. This indicates that Ibrahim's death was after Al-Hajjaj's death, which is correct.

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: The Hiding of Mujahid bin Jabr Abu Al-Hajjaj and Abu Iyad from Al-Hajjaj. 10 - Abu Al-Tahir Al-Sadusi told us, my father told me, Ayyub bin Al-Walid told me, Yahya bin Al-Sakan told us, Shu'bah informed us, Al-Hakam told us, saying:

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: Mujahid and Abu Iyad were hiding from Al-Hajjaj. When the day of Eid arrived, Abu Iyad led them in prayer.

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: The Hiding of Sulayman bin Mahran Abu Muhammad Al-A'mash from Al-Hajjaj. 11 - Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Jabir told us, Ishaq bin Ahmad bin Ja'far told us, Abu Said Al-Ashajj told us, Ibn Fudayl told us on the authority of Al-A'mash who said:

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: He said: We used to hide during the days of Al-Hajjaj in the thickets (Ajam). I was in a thicket with many birds. I would part the reeds, find game, and slaughter it with the reeds. I asked Ibrahim and Al-Sha'bi about that, and they both said: 'It does not harm you what you use to slaughter, as long as you cause the blood to flow (perform Zakat).'

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: The Hiding of Said bin Jubayr from Al-Hajjaj and his Fleeing from him until he was captured. 12 - Abu Ali Al-Narsi told us, Ahmad bin Abdullah bin Shabur told us, Wasil (who is Ibn Abdul A'la) told us, Abu Bakr bin Ayyash told us on the authority of Abu Husayn, who said:

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: I came to Said bin Jubayr in Mecca and said, 'This man is coming (meaning Khalid bin Abdullah), and he has not arrived yet, and I do not trust him regarding you, so obey me and leave.' He said, 'By Allah, I have fled until I am ashamed before Allah Almighty.' So I said, 'By Allah, I see you exactly as your mother named you [Said/Happy].' Abu Bakr bin Ayyash said: And Yazid Abu Abdullah informed me, saying: We came to Said bin Jubayr when he was brought in. He was cheerful, and a little daughter of his was in his lap. She looked at the shackles and cried. He said: So we accompanied him to the prison door. The guards said to him, 'Give us guarantors, for we fear you might drown yourself.' Yazid said: I was among those who guaranteed him. Abu Bakr said: Sulayman said: Some of our companions said: When Said bin Jubayr was killed, Al-Hajjaj said, 'Bring me a wide sword (Ragheeb),' meaning broad, 'and strike the base of the shoulders.' He said: Then he rode for a while after his neck was struck. A man from Quraysh passed by him and threw a fragment of a wall over him (meaning over Said bin Jubayr). 13 - Abu Muhammad Abdullah bin Ja'far bin Al-Ward told us, Yahya bin Ayyub and Abdul Rahman bin Muawiyah Al-Utbi told us, they both said: Amr bin Khald told us, he said: I heard Attab bin Bashir on the authority of Salim Al-Aftas who said: Said bin Jubayr was brought to Al-Hajjaj while on his leg...

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: ...were chains. When he entered upon him, he ordered his neck to be struck. Al-Hajjaj did not stand up from his seat before he became confused and started saying, 'Our chains, our chains.' 14 - Abu Al-Tahir told us, Ibrahim told us, he said: It was said to Said bin Jubayr, 'What does Al-Hasan say if Al-Hajjaj takes a man and tells him to commit kufr (disbelieve)? He permitted him to say that.' Said bin Jubayr said, 'May Allah have mercy on Al-Hasan, a dissimulation (Taqiyyah) in Islam.' 15 - Al-Hasan bin Rashiq told us, Ali bin Said told us, Ibn Abi Umar told us, Sufyan told us on the authority of Salim bin Abi Hafsah, who said: When Said bin Jubayr entered upon Al-Hajjaj, he said to him, 'What is your name?' He said, 'Said bin Jubayr (Happy son of Restorer).' He said, 'No, you are Shaqi bin Kusayr (Wretched son of Broken).' Said said, 'I seek refuge from you with what Maryam, daughter of Imran, sought refuge with the Most Merciful, if you are pious.' He said, 'I will surely kill you.' He said, 'Then I am exactly as my mother named me.' When he was taken to be killed, he said, 'Let me pray two rakats.' Al-Hajjaj said, 'Face him towards the Qibla of the Christians.'

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: When he faced him, he [Said] recited: 'So wherever you turn, there is the Face of Allah.' Muhammad bin Umar Al-Waqidi said: In the year 94, Al-Hajjaj wrote to Khalid bin Abdullah, 'Send me Said bin Jubayr and Talq bin Habib.' So he sent them to him. This is in the book that Ali bin Umar informed me he heard from Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Musta'ini, from Al-Abbas bin Abdullah Al-Bakistani, from Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Umar Al-Waqidi, from his father, from Umar bin Said bin Jubayr, from Ibn Abi Mulaykah. He said: And Ibn Subra told me on the authority of Abdullah bin Uthman bin Khaytham, who said: I saw Said bin Jubayr and Talq bin Habib circumambulating the House (Kaaba) in shackles when they were being taken out to Al-Hajjaj. And he said: Abdullah bin Ja'far told us on the authority of Zakariya bin Amr who said: Khalid took Said bin Jubayr and said, 'You are among those sought by the Commander of the Faithful, yet you are residing in my protection.' So he sent him to Al-Hajjaj. 16 - Abu Muhammad Abdul Aziz bin Muhammad bin Al-Hasan bin Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Khallad Al-Tamimi Al-Jawhari the Judge, grandson of Nu'aym bin Hammad, told us, Muhammad bin Ziyan told us, Salamah bin Shabib told us, Abdul Razzaq told us, Ma'mar informed us, Al-Zuhri informed me, saying: He said: I performed Hajj with Umar bin Abdul Aziz, and he led the people in Hajj during the caliphate of Al-Walid. When we were in Mina, Said bin Jubayr came to me at night while he was hiding from Al-Hajjaj. He said: He said to me,

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: 'Do you fear for your companion here?' He said: I said, 'No, but I will never feel safe.' 17 - Abu Ahmad Al-Sa'di told us, Ja'far bin Ahmad Al-Abdi told us, Ishaq bin Abi Isra'il told us, they both said: Hushaym told us on the authority of Abu Bishr who said: Said bin Jubayr said to me, 'Al-Hajjaj is my killer.' I said, 'Why is that?' He said, 'A dream I saw.' 18 - Hisham bin Khalifa told us, Muhammad bin Murrah Al-Ruayni told us, Abu Ja'far Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Salama told us, Muhammad bin Ja'far bin Hafs told us, he said: I heard Al-Ramadi say: I heard Musaddad say: I heard Yahya Al-Qattan say: I heard Sufyan Al-Thawri mention Said bin Jubayr and say, 'I do not equate anyone from the Tabi'in with him. He remained upon clear insight in his affair until he was killed. I only liken him to Ammar.' 19 - Hisham told us, Abu Ja'far told us, Nuh bin Al-Faraj told us, Abdullah bin Muhammad Al-Fahmi told us, Abdul Rahman bin Al-Qasim told us on the authority of Malik bin Anas who said: Al-Hajjaj brought Said bin Jubayr and Talq bin Habib out of the Kaaba and slaughtered them ruthlessly. 20 - Al-Hasan bin Rashiq told us, Abu Al-Dawlabi told us, Ibrahim bin Yaqub Al-Jawzjani told us, Al-Hasan bin Nafi told us, Hamza told us on the authority of Abu Shawdhab who said: The people were greatly distressed by the capture of Said bin Jubayr in Mecca. Al-Qasri had taken him, so he ascended the pulpit next to the Kaaba and said, 'If the Commander of the Faithful wrote to me to tear this down stone by stone - and he placed his hand on the Kaaba - I would tear it down until I left it as a pond where camels drink.' 21 - Al-Hasan told us, Abu Bishr told us, Ibrahim bin Yaqub told us, Ibrahim bin Musa told me, Isa bin Yunus told us, my father told us, he said: I heard Shahr bin Atiyyah say:

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: When Al-Hajjaj became critically ill, he began saying, 'What do I have to do with Said bin Jubayr?' 22 - Abu Ahmad Al-Sa'di told us, Muhammad bin A'yan told us, Ibn Ayyub Al-Maqabiri told us, Khalaf bin Khalifa told us, a man from the guards (meaning Al-Hajjaj's guards) told us that when Said bin Jubayr's head fell to the ground, it said, 'La ilaha illa Allah' (There is no god but Allah) three times. He said: Twice it spoke clearly, and the third time it said it with a broken tongue.

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: The Hiding of Imran bin Hattan Al-Sadusi from Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf.

book_title: The Hiders who Disappeared out of Fear of Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf Al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Dar Al-Shamiyah - Damascus, Beirut
text: 23 - I asked Abu Al-Hasan Al-Hattabi about his news, and he was related to him by birth through his daughters. So he wrote to me in his own handwriting, and he said in it: Mention of some of his family.

book_title: The Fugitives Who Hid in Fear of Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Al-Dar Al-Shamiyya - Damascus, Beirut
text: When Al-Hajjaj's search for Imran intensified, and he intimidated his people and threatened them because of him, they disagreed over him and mentioned to him their fear of Abd al-Malik, his governors, Al-Hajjaj, and others. So he parted from his people and moved from tribe to tribe until he settled with Ruh ibn Zinba' al-Judhami. While Ruh was one night in a late-night conversation with Abd al-Malik, Abd al-Malik said, 'Do you know who recited this verse: "And regarding whom it was said: How noble is a people whose bellies are the graves of birds... They did not mix their religion with oppression or transgression." Do you know who said it? And can anyone among you add more verses to it for us?' They said, 'No.' He said, 'Whoever brings me knowledge of that shall have from me whatever he asks, beyond the assigned stipends.' Ruh went out and came to his home and said, 'Imran, O Servant of Allah, do you know who recited this poetry?' and he repeated it. Imran said, 'Imran ibn Hittan,' and he recited the poem at length.

book_title: The Fugitives Who Hid in Fear of Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Al-Dar Al-Shamiyya - Damascus, Beirut
text: When Ruh went to Abd al-Malik the next morning, he recited to him the poetry that Imran had recited to him. Abd al-Malik said to him, 'From where did you get this poetry?' He replied...

book_title: The Fugitives Who Hid in Fear of Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Al-Dar Al-Shamiyya - Damascus, Beirut
text: '...from a guest of mine. I have never seen anyone with a better memory than him. I never recited anything to him except that he beat me to it [knew it] and added more to it that I did not know. And I saw his description was such and such; I saw a worshipping man who prays frequently, and I suspect he is from the Haruriyya [Kharijites] of the people of Iraq.' Abd al-Malik said, 'Boy, bring me the scroll of Al-Hajjaj's year.' It was brought, and there was a note. He read his physical description, and behold, it was the description of Imran. Abd al-Malik said, 'Go and bring me your guest, and inform him that he is safe, so he may converse with me for one session.' When Ruh returned to his house, he said to him, 'O Sheikh, the Commander of the Faithful has invited you, so visit him.' He said, 'What do I have to do with the Emir?' He said, 'He has desired that.' He said, 'Then get a letter of safety for me in his own handwriting that I may rely upon.' He said, 'Yes.' Then Ruh came to Abd al-Malik and said, 'O Commander of the Faithful, he desired to have a letter of safety with him in your handwriting and with your seal.'

book_title: The Fugitives Who Hid in Fear of Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Al-Dar Al-Shamiyya - Damascus, Beirut
text: Abd al-Malik said, 'This is one of the tricks of the people of Iraq. The man has gone and left you. However, I see you returning and not finding him.' Ruh returned to his house, and Imran had already left, leaving behind a note in his house containing verses of poetry, which were: 'O Ruh, how many a brother of lodging whom you hosted... thought your thoughts about Lakhm and Ghassan. Until, when I feared him, I departed his home... after it was said: Imran ibn Hittan. I had been your guest for a time, kept awake by no... visitors of mankind or Jinn during it.'

book_title: The Fugitives Who Hid in Fear of Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Al-Dar Al-Shamiyya - Damascus, Beirut
text: 'Until you wanted to take me to the Great One [The Caliph], so I was terrified by... what terrifies people about the generosity of Ibn Marwan. So excuse your brother Ibn Zinba', for indeed... in events, there are tribulations of many colors. One day a Yemenite, if you meet a man of Yemen... and if you meet a Ma'addite, then an Adnani. If I were seeking forgiveness one day from a tyrant... I would have been the foremost in my secrets and my public declarations. However, decisive verses refused that for me... regarding the rulers, in [Surah] Ta-Ha and Imran.' He traveled until he came to Zufar ibn al-Harith al-Kilabi and stayed with him for a time, claiming lineage to Al-Awza', a tribe of Yemen who were Zufar's maternal uncles. A man from those who had been in Ruh's hospitality came to Zufar, and when he saw Imran, he recognized him. Zufar said to him, 'Do you know this man?' He said, 'Yes.'

book_title: The Fugitives Who Hid in Fear of Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Al-Dar Al-Shamiyya - Damascus, Beirut
text: He asked, 'Where did you know him?' He said, 'At Ruh ibn Zinba's.' Zufar asked, 'Who is he?' He replied, 'A man from Azd Shanu'ah.' He said, 'But he claimed he was from Al-Awza'.' Zufar looked at him in astonishment and said, 'An Azdi at one time, and an Awza'i Amr another time. If you told us the truth about your news and informed us who you are; if you are fearful, we will grant you safety, and if you are a fugitive, we will shelter you.' Imran looked at him and laughed, saying, 'Indeed, Allah Almighty is the Sheltera before the Coverer.' The young men of Zufar and the youth of Banu Amir began to pester him. He prayed frequently, and when he prayed, they would mock him by saying, 'Inform us, may Allah have mercy on you.' When they bothered him too much, he departed from them and said: 'Indeed, that which Zufar has become weary of... its inability wearied Ruh ibn Zinba'. He kept asking me for a year for me to inform him... while people are between deceived and deceiver. Until, when the Merciful cut his ropes from me... he stopped asking and did not become fond of panic. So desist as Ruh desisted, for I am a man... either slain or a truffle of the soft earth [meaning insignificant/hidden]. And hold your tongue from insulting and diminishing me... what do you want with an elder of Al-Awza'?'

book_title: The Fugitives Who Hid in Fear of Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Al-Dar Al-Shamiyya - Damascus, Beirut
text: 'How noble is Ruh ibn Zinba' and his family... a tribe that, when a caller calls them to guidance. I was their neighbor for a year while I was frightened... my honor remained intact and my sleep was not fitful. As for prayer, I am not one to abandon it... every man strives for what concerns him. Work, for you are concerned with its events... this gray hair is sufficient as a caller for the intelligent man.' Then he left and settled in Al-Sarat with a clan of Al-Azd who shared his views. He was pleased with what he saw among them and said: 'I settled, praise be to Allah, among the best family... families with whom there is companionship and protection. I settled with a tribe whose gathering Allah unites... for they have no staff other than the Truth to lean upon.'

book_title: The Fugitives Who Hid in Fear of Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Al-Dar Al-Shamiyya - Damascus, Beirut
text: 'From Al-Azd, indeed Al-Azd are the most noble family... of Yemen, on the day when mankind traces their lineage. So I became safe among them, unlike the assembly of people... who came to me saying: From Rabi'ah or Mudar? Or the living Qahtan? And that is foolishness... just as Ruh and his companion Zufar asked me. While we are the children of Islam and the religion is one... and the most worthy of Allah's servants to Allah are those who give thanks. And there is none of them but that he rejoices in a lineage... that brings me closer to him, even if he is a person of numbers [large tribe].' And this is what happened regarding his news. 24 - Abu Tahir al-Sadusi, the judge of Egypt, told us: Muhammad ibn al-Hasan ibn Durayd informed me: Hatim narrated from Abu Ubaydah, who said: Al-Hajjaj expelled Imran ibn Hittan. He was in the lands of Bakr ibn Wa'il between Kufa and Basra, inciting [people] but not witnessing the fighting. A courier came from the Levant from Abd al-Malik, intending to go to Al-Hajjaj. Imran accompanied him for part of the road. He [the courier] saw him to be eloquent and knowledgeable, and the courier was impressed. He said to him, 'I have influence with the Emir; do you have a need I can suffice you with and undertake for you?' He said, 'Yes, you deliver this letter to him.' And he gave him a letter. When he arrived to Al-Hajjaj and finished his errands, he told him the news of the man and said, 'He made me carry a letter.' When he opened it, it contained:

book_title: The Fugitives Who Hid in Fear of Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Al-Dar Al-Shamiyya - Damascus, Beirut
text: 'A lion against me, but in wars an ostrich... with drooping wings, terrified by the whistling of the whistler. Why did you not come out against Ghazala in the battle?... Rather your heart was in the wings of a bird. Ghazala terrified his heart with horsemen... she left his horsemen like yesterday that has passed.'

book_title: The Fugitives Who Hid in Fear of Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Al-Dar Al-Shamiyya - Damascus, Beirut
text: Al-Hajjaj said to him, 'Do you know who he is?' He said, 'No, but I was impressed by what I saw of his novelty.' He said, 'That was Imran ibn Hittan.'

book_title: The Fugitives Who Hid in Fear of Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf al-Thaqafi
publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Al-Dar Al-Shamiyya - Damascus, Beirut
text: The escape of Awn ibn Abdullah from Al-Hajjaj: Mahmud ibn Muhammad the Writer mentioned in his history that Hilal ibn al-Ala told them: Sa'id ibn Salm ibn Qutaybah told us, saying: Awn ibn Abdullah went out with Abu al-Ash'ath, and Al-Hajjaj sought him. So he fled to Muhammad ibn Marwan in Al-Jazira. He granted him refuge and entrusted his son Yazid to him to educate him. He asked him about him after a while, and he [Awn] said: 'If I neglect him, he hides; if I distance myself from him, he complains; if I scold him, he gets angry; and if I answer him, he shouts.'

book_title: The Fugitives Who Hid in Fear of Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf al-Thaqafi

The escape of the Banu Abbas from the Banu Umayyah before the matter came to them: In the book of Mahmud ibn Muhammad the Writer, which he compiled on the history of the people of Al-Jazira, [it is stated] that Abu Wahb Ubayd Allah ibn al-Muthanna ibn Ubayd Allah ibn Amr told him from his father from his grandfather, who said: Abu al-Abbas and Abu Ja'far approached with Amr accompanying them from Humayma, intending for Kufa. They stopped at Dayr al-Qasim, west of Raqqa, out of fear of Zaidah ibn Abi Yahya, the client of Al-Walid. This was the day Uthman ibn Sufyan ibn Harb al-Amiri stayed behind in Raqqa, and he was harsh against the Hashemites and their Shia. A group of the people of Raqqa learned of them. He said: So they gave me a suit of clothes and asked me that Al-Ala told them: Sa'id ibn Salm ibn Qutaybah told us, saying: Awn ibn Abdullah went out with Abu al-Ash'ath, and Al-Hajjaj sought him. So he fled to Muhammad ibn Marwan in Al-Jazira. He granted him refuge and entrusted his son Yazid to him to educate him. He asked him about him after a while, and he said: 'If I neglect him, he hides; if I distance myself from him, he complains; if I scold him, he gets angry; and if I answer him, he shouts.'

He said: So they gave me a suit of clothes and asked me to deliver it to them, and I made excuses for them regarding...

publisher: Dar Al-Qalam, Al-Dar Al-Shamiyya - Damascus, Beirut
text: ...staying behind. Zaidah had become strict, and his supporters in Raqqa had increased, along with their deviation from the Banu Hashim. I did so and warned them against letting anyone know about them, and I informed them that prudence lay in their speedy departure. I heard Abu Ja'far say to Abu al-Abbas, 'If the command comes to us, there will be no benefit in Al-Jazira unless we build a city next to Raqqa,' and he gestured to the location of Al-Rafiqah. When Abu Ja'far became Caliph, he built it in the year one hundred and fifty-five. Its conclusion, and praise be to Allah, the Lord of the Worlds, and may Allah send blessings...
